In this activity we'll find the equation of the line through the points (2,3) and (-1,4), and thereby explain to ourselves why point-slope form works.

li.p: Use the slope formula \displaystyle m = \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} to compute the slope m of the line through the points (2,3) and (-1,4).
A generic point on the line has coordinates (x,y). Use the slope formula to compute the slope of the line through the point (2,3) and the generic point (x,y).
How should your results in part (a) and part (b) be related? (Gasp they're equal bc a straight line has a single constant slope!!!!)
Use the idea of part (c) to solve for y in terms of x. (But what if people simplify so much that it just becomes slope-intercept again?)
